Request specific design movements (Brutalism, Swiss Modernism, etc.) if desired
Specify color preferences, mood, or visual style to guide the philosophy

Review the generated design philosophy to understand the aesthetic choices
Request refinements focusing on cohesion rather than adding more elements

anti_patterns: Requesting text-heavy layouts or long paragraphs (violates minimal text principle)
Asking for cartoon or amateur styles (skill emphasizes sophistication)
Expecting literal illustrations (skill focuses on abstract/conceptual expression)

Copying existing artists' work (violates originality principle)
Overloading with too many competing visual directions in one request

faq.question: What file formats can this skill create?
faq.answer: The skill outputs PDF files (ideal for print) or PNG files (ideal for digital use). Multi-page requests default to PDF format.

faq.question: How much text can I include in a design?
faq.answer: This skill emphasizes minimal text as a visual element. Expect sparse, essential-only typography (titles, key phrases, labels) integrated into the composition rather than lengthy paragraphs or detailed explanations.

faq.question: What is a 'design philosophy' and why does it matter?
faq.answer: The design philosophy is an aesthetic manifesto created before the visual work. It establishes the movement's visual language (form, space, color, composition) and ensures cohesive, intentional design choices rather than random aesthetic decisions.

faq.question: Can I request specific art styles like Brutalism or Swiss Design?
faq.answer: Yes! You can reference established design movements, and the skill will interpret them through its philosophy-first approach. You can also let the skill create entirely new aesthetic movements.

faq.question: What fonts are available?
faq.answer: The skill includes 25+ high-quality open-source fonts: Arsenal SC, Big Shoulders, Boldonse, Bricolage Grotesque, Crimson Pro, DM Mono, Erica One, Geist Mono, Gloock, IBM Plex Mono, Instrument Sans, Italiana, JetBrains Mono, Jura, Libre Baskerville, Lora, National Park, Nothing You Could Do, Outfit, Pixelify Sans, Poiret One, Red Hat Mono, Silkscreen, Smooch Sans, Tektur, Work Sans, and Young Serif.

faq.question: How do I get the best results?
faq.answer: Provide a clear theme or concept, specify any mood/color preferences, and trust the skill's emphasis on craftsmanship. Request refinements that enhance cohesion rather than adding complexity. Think museum-quality, not busy decoration.

faq.question: Can this create infographics or data visualizations?
faq.answer: Not ideally. This skill prioritizes artistic expression and minimal text over information density. For data-heavy work, traditional design tools are more appropriate.

faq.question: What does 'subtle conceptual reference' mean?
